subject: Comparative Study of Major Religions (CSS Pakistan)

notes.title: Official Scope & Syllabus
notes.content: Start with FPSC's official syllabus to anchor topics: definitions of religion, world religious landscape, and core sections on Hinduism, Buddhism, Judaism, Christianity, Islam.
keyTakeaways: Know alternatives (Islamic Studies OR Comparative Religions) and 100-mark structure.
Use syllabus headings to build your notebook and weekly goals.

resources.title: FPSC — Revised Syllabi CE-2016 & onwards (PDF)
resources.description: Official policy; notes option for non-Muslims.

notes.title: Past-Paper Mapping & Recurring Question Types
notes.content: Build a bank of recurring prompts in five clusters: descriptive essays, comparative ethics, note-writing on texts/rituals, historical/biographical analysis, and interfaith harmony.
keyTakeaways: Convert each past prompt into an outline + 5–7 talking points.
Tag questions by religion/theme for spaced revision.

resources.title: CSS Past Papers—Comparative Religions (compiled)
resources.description: Use for trends and drill prompts.

notes.title: Comparative Ethics: Ten Commandments ↔ Islamic Moral Teachings
notes.content: Understand content and function of Decalogue (Exodus 20) and compare with Qur'anic ethics (monotheism, justice, compassion, honesty, family duties).
keyTakeaways: Map commandment-to-virtue pairs (e.g., truthfulness, property, worship).
Show convergences and doctrinal differences respectfully.

resources.title: Britannica — Islam: Doctrines of the Qur'an

notes.title: Buddhism: Four Noble Truths & Eightfold Path
notes.content: Master doctrinal core (dukkha, origin, cessation, path) and the Eightfold Path for ethical–meditative–wisdom structure.
keyTakeaways: Use precise phrasing of each 'Right' factor.
Link ethics (sila) → meditation (samadhi) → insight (prajna).

notes.title: Hinduism: Bhagavad Gita—Duty, Devotion, Discipline
notes.content: Use the Gita to discuss dharma, karma-yoga, bhakti, and the tension between renunciation and action.
keyTakeaways: Quote with context (dialogue of Krishna–Arjuna).
Show how Gita frames ethical action without attachment.

notes.title: Judaism: Tanakh, Talmud & Maimonides' Thirteen Principles
notes.content: Know structure of Tanakh; appreciate Talmud's role; summarize Maimonides' creed.
keyTakeaways: Differentiate Written vs. Oral Torah; Bavli's authority.
Use one-line summaries of the 13 principles.

notes.title: Christianity: Catholic–Protestant Differences & Atonement
notes.content: Outline major contrasts (authority, sacraments, Mary/saints, papacy), and summarize atonement models (ransom, satisfaction, penal substitution, moral influence).
keyTakeaways: Tie differences to history of Reformation.
Use atonement as a case study of reason–revelation interplay.

notes.title: Islam: Ethics, Law & Theology (Kalām)
notes.content: Summarize Qur'anic moral vision (justice, compassion, truthfulness), Islamic law's ethical aims, and theological debates (e.g., reason & morality in Muʿtazila).
keyTakeaways: Use examples of ethical injunctions and maqasid (objectives).
Note role of reason alongside revelation in some schools.

notes.title: Sacred Texts: Quick Access Pack
notes.content: Keep authoritative portals for quick quotation and cross-checking.
keyTakeaways: Verify chapter/verse; cite translation/version.
Use parallel references where helpful.

notes.title: Reason vs Revelation (Cross-Tradition)
notes.content: Frame classic debates (e.g., Christian theology on reason/faith; Islamic kalām on reason/morality).
keyTakeaways: Define terms carefully; avoid strawmen.
Use case examples (ethics without revelation; natural law).

resources.title: Stanford Encyclopedia — Sin in Christian Thought (context for atonement/incarnation)

notes.title: Interfaith Harmony: Frameworks & Policy
notes.content: Use reputable frameworks for defining and practicing inter-/intrafaith dialogue in essays.
keyTakeaways: Cite definitions and practical toolkits (UNESCO, etc.).
Connect dialogue to social cohesion and peace metrics.

resources.title: UN Press — Culture of Peace & Interreligious Dialogue (UNGA)

notes.title: Demography & Trends (use for 'contemporary relevance')
notes.content: Back claims with up-to-date cross-country data to avoid anecdotal arguments.
keyTakeaways: Always date your stats; note source methodology.
Use country-level tables for Pakistan/world comparisons.

notes.title: Biographical Essays: Shah Waliullah, Sirhindi, others
notes.content: Organize life → context → teachings → reforms → societal impact → comparative insight.
keyTakeaways: Tie biography to interfaith/social ethics where appropriate.
End with a 3-point 'modern relevance' section.

notes.title: Essay Templates for Comparative Questions
notes.content: Ready-to-deploy skeletons for Ten Commandments vs Islamic ethics; Buddhist ethics vs Abrahamic codes; Catholic vs Protestant doctrines.
keyTakeaways: Intro with definition + scope; 2–3 balanced comparisons; counter-view; synthesis.
Use mixed evidence: scripture + scholarship + data.

resources.title: Harvard Writing Center — Strategies for Essay Writing (PDF)

notes.title: Comparative Drill Set (Problem–Solution, Causal, Analytical)
notes.content: Daily 30-minute drills: outline two comparative prompts; write one 10-minute paragraph practicing transitions and evidence use.
keyTakeaways: Rotate traditions to stay balanced.
Peer-review against a rubric weekly.

notes.title: Christian Atonement: Models & Sources
notes.content: Use concise definitions and examples for ransom, satisfaction, penal substitution, moral influence; connect to ethics and social teaching.
keyTakeaways: Cite a primary/secondary definition; avoid caricatures.
Show how models shape views on justice/mercy.

notes.title: Judaism: Talmud Basics & Study Aids
notes.content: Differentiate Jerusalem vs Babylonian Talmuds; know Mishna/Gemara; appreciate contemporary study culture.
keyTakeaways: Use one 'how it's structured' diagram in notes.
Quote responsibly; prefer Sefaria translations.

notes.title: Pluralism & Case Studies
notes.content: Use Harvard Pluralism Project for concise overviews, case vignettes, and classroom-ready examples of interreligious encounters.
keyTakeaways: Pull 2–3 case studies to exemplify tolerance/dialogue.
Connect cases to Pakistan/region where relevant.

notes.title: Quotations & Allusions (Use Carefully)
notes.content: Keep a small bank of accurate, sourced quotations (e.g., Decalogue lines; Gita couplets). Always provide context and avoid overuse.
keyTakeaways: Attribute correctly; avoid decontextualized aphorisms.
Prefer authoritative editions and portals.

notes.title: Exam-Day Strategy (Comparative Religions)
notes.content: Allocate 12 min to outline (definitions, scope, plan); 70–75 min to draft; 10–15 min to revise. Balance traditions and avoid biased tone.
keyTakeaways: Define terms, then compare on clear criteria (ethics, ritual, theology).
Cite at least one primary & one reputable secondary source.
